name: 黃光廷
objective:
This course aims to introduce students to key theoretical and methodological approaches in urban design. The main content will be delivered through a series of case study discussion and project-based research practice. In specific, the case study is to review and identify key factors shaping the physical environment of cities; while through independent research projects, students are expected to engage in a step-by-step process of on-site observation and computational analysis, examining how the factors are interacting with each other.

Note: Competency in the basic use of computer is required. In class, the instructor will provide tutorials about how to use the computational analysis tool (Space Syntax).

Office Hour: Tuesday 16:00-17:00
schedule:
1. Defining the City
2. Evolving Urban Form
3. Alternative Visions of Good City
4. Transformative Practice of Urban Design
5. Methods of Spatial Analysis I
6. Methods of Spatial Analysis II 
7. Case Study Seminar I
8. Case Study Seminar II
9. Mid-term Presentation
10. Methods of Computational Analysis I
11. Methods of Computational Analysis II
12. City in the Age of Globalization
13. Limits and Biases of Contemporary Urban Design
14. Sustainable City
15. Pin-up Critique I
16. Pin-up Critique II
17. Final Presentation I
18. Final Presentation II
scorePolicy:
10% Attendance
20% Participation
30% In-class Presentation
40% Research Project (Presentation/Report)
materials:
Rybczynski, Witold. (2010). Makeshift Metropolis: Ideas about Cities. New York: Scribner.
Kaijima, M., Kuroda J. and Tsukamoto Y. (2001). Made in Tokyo. Tokyo: Kajima Institute Publishing Co.
Al-Sayed, K. (2014). Space Syntax Methodology. London: Bartlett School of Architecture, UCL.
